TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties and as they appear from the documents on the file , may be summarised as follows .

The police investigated allegations that a bank had advanced loans without the necessary guarantees to such an extent that its solvency had been endangered and that unlawful financial inducements had been offered . The investigation also focused on whether there had been debtor dishonesty or fraud .
On DATE the applicant was questioned by the police as a suspect and he was subsequently charged with CARDINAL counts of economic crime allegedly committed in DATE .

On DATE the ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) upheld the applicant ’s claim that he had not been properly summoned to the trial and declared the case against him inadmissible . On DATE ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) upheld the decision . On DATE ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) quashed the previous decisions and remitted the case to ORG .

Meanwhile , a second hearing was held on DATE . On DATE the applicant was charged with aggravated fraud allegedly committed in DATE . At the third hearing on DATE , ORG upheld his claim that he had not been properly summoned . On DATE ORG quashed the decision . On DATE ORG upheld the appellate court ’s decision .
At the same hearing on DATE the public prosecutor was found to be biased and a new prosecutor was assigned to the case , which was then adjourned until DATE .

On DATE ORG upheld co - defendant X ’s claim that he had not been properly summoned and that the statute of limitations had already expired . On DATE ORG quashed the decision and remitted the case to the lower court . On DATE ORG upheld the appellate court ’s decision .

Meanwhile , on DATE ORG noted in its minutes that the parties disagreed as to whether the “ reasonable time ” requirement in LAW had been complied with , and that the court would decide at a later stage whether the trial could continue .

On DATE ORG issued a separate decision dismissing the applicant ’s request that the charges against him be declared inadmissible due to the length of the proceedings . It held , inter alia , that the case was exceptionally difficult , involving voluminous evidence and being of significant public interest . On DATE it dismissed the applicant ’s renewed request . On DATE the applicant lodged a procedural complaint with the appellate court . It was dismissed on DATE .
There were DATE of hearings in ORG up to DATE , held at intervals of DATE .

On DATE a NORP court acceded to the request of ORG for the extradition of the applicant , who was residing in GPE at the time , to GPE to serve a prison sentence which had previously been imposed on him . According to an arrangement , the applicant would be granted immunity from further prosecution in GPE for offences he had previously committed .
On DATE ORG found that the criminal case against the applicant was barred on the basis of immunity .

On DATE ORG applied to the NORP authorities for permission to continue the applicant ’s prosecution in GPE in respect of offences other than those for which he had been extradited . On DATE the relevant NORP court acceded to the request . The applicant ’s appeal was rejected on DATE . On DATE the NORP Government consented to his continued prosecution in GPE .

The applicant challenged the lawfulness of the continued prosecution before the NORP courts . During DATE he changed counsel . On DATE ORG rejected his claim for continued immunity , finding that the immunity had been annulled by the afore - mentioned decision of ORG . The decision was upheld by ORG on DATE .
The present case was adjourned until DATE owing to the need to replace the public prosecutor , who had fallen ill .

Meanwhile , on DATE and DATE respectively ORG dismissed the applicant ’s further requests that the charges be ruled inadmissible owing to the length of the proceedings . On DATE it also dismissed his renewed request , observing that the question of whether the length of the proceedings had been unreasonable would be examined in due course and that any redress required could be given at the end of the proceedings . The appellate court upheld the last - mentioned decision on DATE . On DATE ORG refused leave to appeal .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s renewed request to have the charges against him declared inadmissible on account of the length of the proceedings .

During the trial the police conducted CARDINAL additional investigations , the last of which , according to the Government ’s observations in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , DATE ) , was completed on DATE .
There had been a total of DATE of hearings DATE when ORG had started to obtain evidence . Thereafter , there were DATE of hearings up until DATE .

On DATE ORG , noting that he lacked competence to interfere with the ongoing proceedings , drew the ORG ’s attention to the need for the allocation of adequate financial resources to both ORG and the authorities involved in the case .
On DATE the ORG gave its judgment . It found that the “ reasonable time ” requirement laid down in the LAW and the LAW had not been respected .

The court dismissed as time - barred the charges concerning CARDINAL counts of debtor dishonesty and acquitted the applicant of CARDINAL counts of aggravated fraud . Finally , it dismissed the charge of debtor dishonesty . It ordered the applicant and CARDINAL co - defendants jointly to pay damages in the amount of MONEY ( ORG ) , together with interest from DATE .
The public prosecutor appealed . ORG held CARDINAL preparatory hearings in DATE . In the main hearing the case was heard over DATE in DATE .

On DATE ORG gave its judgment , convicting the applicant of aggravated fraud . It concurred with the lower court that the “ reasonable time ” requirement had not been respected and that the applicant was therefore entitled to redress , which had to be significant and substantial . It also had to be given in a clear and measurable manner . No reason had emerged not to impose a sentence . The court , however , found that the applicant had contributed to the length of the proceedings as , at the time when the summonses were served , he had been abroad and thereby been difficult to reach . Nevertheless , the court stated that it would reduce the applicant ’s sentence by CARDINAL owing to the lengthy proceedings .

Having noted the length of the standard sentence for the aggravated fraud in question and having as a mitigating factor taken into account that the sentence could have been imposed at the time of the imposition of the applicant ’s previous sentences ( which would have been more advantageous for the applicant ) and in that connection the so - called maximum sentence rule laid down by LAW , LAW , of LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflagen ; as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) , ORG noted that CARDINAL days’ imprisonment would have been appropriate had the proceedings not been excessively lengthy . However , owing to the breach of the “ reasonable time ” requirement , ORG sentenced him to an immediate term of CARDINAL days’ imprisonment . It applied LAW , article DATE , of LAW ( as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL which took effect on DATE ) . Having regard to the seriousness of the applicant ’s offence , the damage thereby caused and the considerable advantage pursued and achieved , the court considered that the maintaining of general obedience to the law required that the prison term be an immediate one . The CARDINAL latter factors led the court to conclude that community service was not an option .
The applicant requested leave to appeal to ORG , which was refused on DATE .
LAW , article CARDINAL , point CARDINAL of the Penal Code reads :
“ In addition to what is provided above in section CARDINAL , grounds for mitigating the sentence that are also to be taken into consideration are
( CARDINAL ) a considerably long period that has passed since the commission of the offence ;
if the punishment that accords with established practice would for these reasons lead to an unreasonable or exceptionally detrimental result . ”
LAW , article CARDINAL , point CARDINAL , of the Penal Code provides :
“ The court may waive the sentence if

CARDINAL ) the imposition of a sentence must be considered unreasonable or purposeless especially having regard to the factors mentioned in LAW , article CARDINAL , point CARDINAL and LAW , article CARDINAL or the measures taken by social and health services ;

In its judgment of DATE ( ORG CARDINAL ) ORG noted that , although there were no legal provisions justifying the dismissal of a criminal charge due to unreasonably long proceedings , such a dismissal or declaration of inadmissibility might in some exceptional circumstances , for example if their duration ruled out a good defence , be the only effective remedy satisfying the requirements of LAW . That was , however , not the case here . In considering whether there were grounds for applying LAW , article DATE , of LAW , ORG held that it had to be decided in PERSON whether the duration of the proceedings ( here over DATE ) had been unreasonable . It concluded that , in this case , there were no grounds not to impose a sentence or to mitigate the sentence owing to the duration of the proceedings .

In its judgment of DATE ( ORG CARDINAL ) ORG , applying LAW , article DATE , of LAW , reduced the sentence by DATE owing to the lengthy proceedings ( DATE ) . It imposed an immediate term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , finding that it was not justifiable to further mitigate the sentence by suspending the term of imprisonment .

On DATE ORG delivered a judgment ( ORG CARDINAL:CARDINAL ) in which , applying LAW , article CARDINAL , point CARDINAL , of LAW , it afforded redress for the breach of the “ reasonable time ” requirement ( here the proceedings had lasted DATE ) by waiving the sentence .
